text:
Q: How do I enable custom treatment of onBackpress in Android? A:

I want to avoid using AndroidX

See the documentation for more on what changed in this area in Android 16 and what to do about it, including what to do when you are not using AndroidX.

Their example code is... not great, in that it refers to BuildCompat, which is from the Jetpack, and it refers to a function (isAtLeastT()) that is deprecated. Replace it with Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= 33:

@Override
void onCreate() {
  if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= 33) {
    getOnBackInvokedDispatcher().registerOnBackInvokedCallback(
        OnBackInvokedDispatcher.PRIORITY_DEFAULT,
        () -> {
          /**
           * onBackPressed logic goes here - For instance:
           * Prevents closing the app to go home screen when in the
           * middle of entering data to a form
           * or from accidentally leaving a fragment with a WebView in it
           *
           * Unregistering the callback to stop intercepting the back gesture:
           * When the user transitions to the topmost screen (activity, fragment)
           * in the BackStack, unregister the callback by using
           * OnBackInvokeDispatcher.unregisterOnBackInvokedCallback
           * (https://developer.android.com/reference/kotlin/android/view/OnBackInvokedDispatcher#unregisteronbackinvokedcallback)
           */
        }
    );
  }
}

Doesn't recognize getOnBackInvokedDispatcher()

That was added in API Level 33, back in 2022. Set your compileSdk (or compileSdkVersion) in your build.gradle file for your module to 33 or higher, preferably 36.

Q: Programming with Threads in Java A:

My question is, will nn point to the object of the Thread class or just call method start() and after that method run() by itself?

It's both:

  • nn will reference the NT4 instance as you wrote NT4 nn = new NT4();. If you don't change the value of the variable nn, it will continue referencing the object you have created.
  • The constructor of NT4 will call the start() method, which will start the thread, which will execute the run() method.

So you will have a reference to the NT4 instance, which is a thread executing the run() method.

Q: Android rotation disturbs my screen animation A:

One option is to tell android that you will handle when the screen changes orientation, so that onCreate() is not called again when the screen changes orientations. To do this, add an entry for the specific activity in your manifest file. It should look something like this:

<activity
        android:name="com.package.name.Activity"
        android:configChanges="orientation"
        android:label="@string/title_activity"
        android:parentActivityName="com.package.name.Parent" >
        <meta-data
            android:name="android.support.PARENT_ACTIVITY"
            android:value="com.package.name.Parent" />
</activity>

the line android:configChanges is what I'm referring to

Q: Cutting rows beginning with letter and past them after last cell of row beginning with number A:

Or maybe simpler:

=LET(data,A26:F36,REDUCE("",data,LAMBDA(x,y,IF(N(y),IFNA(VSTACK(x,TOROW(TAKE(y:TAKE(data,-1),2),1)),""),x))))

This is provided that the data is always in two rows starting from the line containing the number, like in your example.

Q: WebMvcTest security unit tests no longer working with Spring Boot 4 A:

Last time i checked...in Spring Boot 4 (Spring Security 7), @WebMvcTest no longer reflects the real servlet filter lifecycle.

The MVC test slice backed by MockMvc can invoke registered filters during request setup and handler mapping resolution, before FilterChainProxy does request matching.

That early invocation can trigger a OncePerRequestFilter outside the actual security filter chain, which does not happen in a real servlet container.

This is a known mismatch of the MVC test slice, not an issue in your JWT filter or security config.

There is no supported way to make@WebMvcTestbehave like production here, so asserting security filter behavior in that slice is invalid.

The correct approach is to use @SpringBootTest with @AutoConfigureMockMvc(addFilters = true ), or keep @WebMvcTest but disable and mock security.

Otherwise you are asserting against internal test harness behavior that changed in Boot 4; the application itself is fine, the test is not appropriate for this concern.

check this section

Q: Shopify site is responsive on web browser but not iPhone A:

Maybe you are missing a closing bracket. Check your all media query brackets.

Safari is not closing brackets automatically like other browsers.

Q: Why is Markdig parsing my PipelineTables as Paragraphs? A:

The problem was that I was calling Markdown.Parse(markdownString) without the pipeline, so it wasn't getting access to the table configuration.
